The weight upon my spirit was sensibly lightened as I plunged yet deeper in the ravine of Arve.
the river Arve, whose course we followed, closed in upon us by degrees;
the river Arve, whose course we followed, closed in upon us by degrees;
the river Arve, whose course we followed, closed in upon us by degrees;

The immense mountains and precipices that overhung me on every side—the sound of the river raging among the rocks, and the dashing of the <pb n="79" xml:id="F1831_v_095"/>waterfalls around, spoke of a power mighty as Omnipotence—and I ceased to fear, or to bend before any being less almighty than that which had created and ruled the elements, here displayed in their most terrific guise. Still,
immense mountains and precipices overhanging us on every side, and heard the sound of the river raging among rocks, and the dashing of water-falls around.

A tingling long-lost sense of pleasure often came across me during

journey. Some turn in the road, some new object suddenly perceived and recognised, reminded me of days gone by, and were associated with the light-hearted gaiety of boyhood. The very winds whispered in soothing accents, and maternal nature bade me weep no more. Then again the kindly influence ceased to act—I found myself fettered again to grief,

pursued its noisy way beneath. The same lulling sounds acted as a lullaby to my too keen sensations: when I placed my head upon my pillow, sleep crept over me; I felt it as it came, and blest the giver of oblivion.
